Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS)

justification: Anaphylaxis is a severe, potentially life-threatening allergic reaction. It often presents with a combination of symptoms including hives (urticaria), angioedema (swelling beneath the skin), respiratory distress (including nasal congestion), and syncope (fainting) due to a drop in blood pressure.}, {diagnosis: Allergic reaction (non-anaphylactic)

justification: Milder allergic reactions can still cause a combination of hives, angioedema, and nasal congestion. While less likely to cause syncope than anaphylaxis, it is possible if the allergic reaction progresses.}, {diagnosis: Drug allergy

justification: Many medications can trigger allergic reactions, ranging from mild to severe. Symptoms like hives, angioedema, nasal congestion, and in severe cases, syncope, can occur.}, {diagnosis: Food allergy

justification: Similar to drug allergies, food allergies can also cause a spectrum of reactions. Common triggers for severe reactions include peanuts, tree nuts, shellfish, and fish, and can manifest with hives, angioedema, nasal congestion, and syncope.}, {diagnosis: Insect sting allergy

justification: Venom from stinging insects like bees, wasps, and hornets can cause severe allergic reactions. Symptoms like hives, angioedema, nasal congestion, and syncope can occur, particularly in individuals with known allergies.}, {diagnosis: Mastocytosis

justification: Mastocytosis is a rare disorder characterized by an abnormal accumulation of mast cells in the body. These cells release histamine and other chemicals that can cause symptoms like hives, angioedema, nasal congestion, and in some cases, syncope due to low blood pressure.}, {diagnosis: Hereditary angioedema

justification: This rare genetic condition causes episodes of swelling in various parts of the body, including the face, throat, and intestines.  While it doesnt directly cause hives or nasal congestion, the swelling can mimic nasal congestion. Syncope is possible due to airway obstruction or dehydration from vomiting and diarrhea that can accompany attacks.}, {diagnosis: Vasovagal syncope

justification: While not directly related to the other symptoms, vasovagal syncope is a common cause of fainting and can be triggered by various stimuli. Its possible the patient experienced syncope separate from the other symptoms, or a severe allergic reaction triggered a vasovagal response.}, {diagnosis: Panic attack

justification: Though not a primary cause of the physical symptoms listed, extreme anxiety and panic attacks can sometimes manifest with physical symptoms that mimic an allergic reaction.  In rare cases, hyperventilation during a panic attack can lead to syncope.}, {diagnosis: Idiopathic urticaria / angioedema

justification: When a specific cause for hives and angioedema cannot be identified, it is classified as idiopathic. These episodes may be accompanied by nasal congestion and, in some cases, syncope, even in the absence of a clear allergic trigger.}
